note: Garfinkel and Ganor 2009; Garfinkel and Kang 2011).
title: The early Iron IIA casemate fortification at Khirbet Qeiyafa would seem to be a clear parallel to the casemate fortification of Stratum 3C
Gibson has communicated that his ongoing analysis of Pritchard’s excavations of Gibeon (el-Jib) shows that Pritchard’s “early wall
should be dated to the 10th century BCE on the basis of the ceramic material (personal communication). an ar chaeologic al sur ve y of juda h i n t h e l at e i r on i i a | 105
For a summary of the different views on the ethnicity and national affiliations of Khirbet Qeiyafa see Levin’s comments
Khirbet ed-Dawwara means “the ruin of the circle” or the “round one
163). The name is likely due to the clear circular shape of the ruin formed by the casemate fortification
Aharoni believed that this reflected Sennacherib’s attack against Jerusalem

note: The geographical context of both passages argues strongly for these identifications, although see Schultz (2010) who identifies “Tamar in the wilderness” (1 Kings 9:17) as Jericho.
title: See Lott’s discussion of the textual problems associated with the different mentions of Tamar, Teman, and Tadmor

Aharoni’s discussion is particularly helpful with regards to solving the problem (1979, 319). It would seem that the best solution to the textual problem is to associate the 1 Kings 9:8 with Tamar of En Hazeva and the Tadmor of 2 Chronicles 8:3 as the Tadmor between Mari and Damascus
and the excavations, together with the abundant extra-biblical texts, have all but confirmed En-Hazeva’s identity with that of Tamar
